facts: Mercury is the smallest planet in the Solar System.
Mercury has the shortest orbit around the Sun, completing it in just about 88 Earth days.
Mercury has extreme temperature variations, with highs reaching around 800°F (427°C) during the day and dropping to -290°F (-180°C) at night.
Venus is often called Earth's 'sister planet' because of their similar size, composition, and proximity to the Sun.

Venus has a thick atmosphere primarily composed of carbon dioxide, which creates a strong greenhouse effect, making it the hottest planet in the Solar System with surface temperatures reaching about 900°F (475°C).
Venus rotates in the opposite direction to most planets, a phenomenon called retrograde rotation.
Earth is the only planet known to support life.
Earth is mostly covered in water, about 71% of its surface.
Earth's atmosphere is composed of roughly 78% nitrogen, 21% oxygen, and trace amounts of other gases.
Mars is often called the 'Red Planet' due to its reddish appearance caused by iron oxide (rust) on its surface.
Mars has the largest volcano in the Solar System, Olympus Mons, which is about 13.6 miles (22 kilometers) high and 370 miles (600 kilometers) in diameter.
Mars has two small moons, Phobos and Deimos.
Jupiter is the largest planet in the Solar System, with a diameter over 11 times that of Earth.
Jupiter has a strong magnetic field, which is about 14 times stronger than Earth's.
Jupiter's Great Red Spot is a massive storm that has been raging for at least 400 years.
Saturn is famous for its beautiful and extensive ring system, composed mostly of ice particles and dust.
Saturn has the second-largest moon in the Solar System, Titan, which is larger than the planet Mercury.
Saturn is the least dense planet in the Solar System; if there were an ocean large enough, Saturn would float on it.
Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun and was the first planet discovered with the aid of a telescope.
Uranus is unique among the planets because it rotates on its side, possibly due to a collision with another large body in its past.
Uranus has a faint ring system and 27 known moons.
Neptune is the eighth and farthest known planet from the Sun.
Neptune's atmosphere is primarily composed of hydrogen, helium, and methane, giving it a blue color.
Neptune has the strongest winds in the Solar System, with gusts reaching up to 1,500 miles per hour (2,400 kilometers per hour).
